resources.string: Allows Taskbar to launch apps in freeform window mode, for a more desktop-like experience.\n\nThis feature is experimental, and may cause issues with standard split-screen multitasking.

Taskbar: PC-style productivity for Android

Nothing to see here, move along…

Unfortunately, due to OEM restrictions, this feature can't be enabled on your device.

You may still be able to enable it by using this adb shell command:

appops set %1$s %2$s allow
Show shortcut icon for pinned apps

In order for Taskbar to launch apps in freeform window mode, please follow these steps:

• Go to Developer Options

• Scroll to the bottom and turn on "%s"

• Reboot your device
Hide button while Taskbar is collapsed

About freeform mode

Taskbar lets you launch apps in freeform floating windows on Android 7.0+ devices. No root access is required, although Android 8.0, 8.1, and 9 devices require an adb shell command to be run during initial setup.

Simply follow these steps to configure your device for launching apps in freeform mode:

1. Check the box for "Freeform window support" inside the Taskbar app

2. Follow the directions that appear in the pop-up to enable the proper settings on your device (one-time setup)

3. Go to your device's recent apps page and clear all recent apps

4. Start Taskbar, then select an app to launch it in a freeform window

For best results, especially on Android 8.0 and 8.1, restart your device before using freeform mode

Window size presets

Taskbar can launch app windows in various preset sizes. You can choose a window size by long-pressing or right-clicking an app icon and selecting "New window."

To save a window size preset for a specific app, simply long-press the preset, and a checkmark will appear indicating that it is set as default. Taskbar will launch the app using this selected size on subsequent launches.

Note that window sizes don't work correctly on Android 8.0 and 8.1. However, you can work around this by launching the app, immediately closing it, then launching it again from Android's overview menu.

Troubleshooting

• Apps still launch fullscreen

If an app is launched that is already loaded into memory, Taskbar will bring it into the foreground. In order to launch the app into freeform mode, it has to be launched from a fresh state.

Swipe the app away from recents, and then re-launch it from the recent apps page using Taskbar. If this doesn't work, then long-press the app icon, select "App info," and then force stop the app. Alternatively, you can restart your device.

• Apps that are maximized cannot be restored into a window

If you press the Maximize button on an app's title bar, Android will bring the app out of freeform mode and into fullscreen mode. As mentioned above, Taskbar can only launch apps into freeform windows if they are launched from a fresh state.

To fix this, you can maximize windows by tapping or clicking just outside the app's window frame. This will expand the window to fill all the available space while keeping it in the freeform window workspace.

• Maximizing windows doesn't work on Android 9

This functionality is beyond Taskbar's control and is something that Google needs to fix on their end. If you need to maximize a window on Android 9, please use the "Maximized" window size instead.

• App transitions don't seem to work properly, especially on Android 9

This is also an issue that Google needs to fix on their end, however, you can work around it by disabling app transitions.

You can disable transitions when launching an app by going to Taskbar's recent apps settings and enabling the "Faster app switching" option. Alternatively, you can disable transitions system-wide by going to developer options and setting "Transition animation scale" to "Animation off."

%1$s can optionally show icons for your most recently used apps along the edge of your screen. To do this, %1$s requires usage access permissions.\n\n
To enable support for recent apps, press \"Open Settings\" to open the Android TV app settings menu. Select \"Special app access\", then select \"Usage access\" and ensure that Taskbar is enabled.
Please ensure that %s is set to \"On\"
Allows Taskbar to perform button press actions

Taskbar needs to be activated as an accessibility service in order to perform button press actions such as back, home, recents, and power, as well as displaying the notification tray.\n\nThis permission is used only to perform button press actions, and for no other purpose.

Ensure that usage access is enabled before changing this setting.\n\nHigher values may reduce performance.
Ensure that usage access is enabled before changing this setting.\n\nLower values will increase CPU usage and may decrease battery life.

Custom ROMs based on CyanogenMod / LineageOS have an issue where the power button does not work while the device is in freeform mode.\n\nPlease test your power button now. If it does not work, then exercise caution when using freeform mode as you may lose the ability to wake the device from sleep if the screen times out.

In order for Taskbar to launch apps in freeform window mode, please follow these steps:

• Go to Developer Options and enable USB debugging

• Connect your device to a computer with the Android SDK installed, and run the following command (one-line):

adb shell settings put global enable_freeform_support 1

• Reboot your device

To configure your device for desktop mode, please follow these steps:

• Go to Developer Options

• Scroll to the bottom and turn on "Enable freeform windows" and "Force desktop mode"

• Set Taskbar as your default home app

• Reboot your device

For more information and troubleshooting steps, click the (?) icon in the upper-right hand corner of the screen.
Reboot your device to complete desktop mode setup

Taskbar can optionally use elevated permissions to improve your desktop mode experience. These permissions are granted by running an adb shell command.\n\nIf you wish to continue, connect your device to a computer with the Android SDK installed, and run the following command (one line):
Once granted, the additional settings will be enabled when a display is connected.

Use Taskbar to launch windowed apps on an external display, similar to Samsung DeX and other solutions.\n\nRequires either a USB-to-HDMI adapter, or a lapdock, and a device that supports video output.
Click here for info on how to enable

About desktop mode

Taskbar supports Android 10's built-in desktop mode functionality. You can connect your compatible Android 10+ device to an external display and run apps in resizable windows, with Taskbar's interface running on your external display and your existing launcher still running on your phone.

Desktop mode requires a USB-to-HDMI adapter (or a lapdock), and a compatible device that supports video output. Additionally, certain settings require granting a special permission via adb.

To get started, tick the checkbox for "Desktop mode." The app will guide you through the one-time setup process, which involves:

• Enabling the "Enable freeform windows" and "Force desktop mode" developer options

• Setting Taskbar as your default home app

• Rebooting your device

Why does Taskbar need to be set as my default home app for desktop mode to work?

By design, Android will only allow the default home app to act as the launcher for desktop mode on external displays. If the currently set home app does not specifically declare support for desktop mode, then Android will fall back to using a predefined desktop mode interface.

Taskbar is able to work around this limitation by acting as a shim between the system and your preferred launcher. When Taskbar is set as your home app, when the home button is pressed it will immediately start the launcher you prefer to use on your phone, then quit. This launcher is set within Taskbar's desktop mode preferences by clicking on the "Primary launcher" setting.

There are a couple of caveats to keep in mind when Taskbar is set as your home app:

• Most app shortcuts (seen when long-pressing an app icon) will no longer be available to your primary launcher. This is due to an Android system limitation where only the default home app has access to app shortcuts that are dynamically created.

• Certain animations that occur when pressing the home button may look incorrect. This is due to the aforementioned behavior where Taskbar acts as a shim when the home button is pressed.

How do I know if my device supports video output to external displays?

The folks over at NexDock maintain a list of Android 10+ smartphones that are compatible with USB-to-HDMI video output (this list excludes Samsung and Huawei devices). You can view this list here: http://nexdock.com/lapdock-for-smartphones

Google Pixel devices, notably, do not include support for video output. However, you can still use Taskbar with standard screen mirroring on these devices, either via Chromecast or by using a DisplayLink dock coupled with the DisplayLink Presenter app.

Should I use Taskbar's desktop mode over my device's built-in desktop mode solution, such as Samsung DeX?

Some OEMs, such as Samsung and Huawei, have implemented their own version of desktop mode, building on top of Google's implementation in Android 10. These solutions have better integration with the rest of the system and are generally more polished overall. There is no need to switch over to Taskbar if you're happy with your device's existing desktop mode solution.

Taskbar's desktop mode support is geared towards devices that don't offer a built-in desktop mode solution beyond what Google ships as stock with Android 10.

I can't find the "Force desktop mode" toggle in developer options – can I still use desktop mode?

Some devices (such as the ASUS ROG Phone 2) do not have the "Force desktop mode" toggle in developer options. You will need to enable that option manually via adb. To do so, connect your device to a computer with the Android SDK installed, and run the following command (one-line):

adb shell settings put global force_desktop_mode_on_external_displays 1

What should I do if something goes wrong or my launcher / apps behave funky when desktop mode is enabled?

Please follow these steps to disable desktop mode in case anything goes wrong:

• Pull down the quick settings drawer, then enter system settings via the gear icon

• Navigate to developer options and disable "Enable freeform support" and "Force desktop mode"

• Reboot your device
See what\'s new in this release
Fixes visual glitches caused by input methods on Android 11+. Requires you to temporarily set Taskbar as your input method each time desktop mode starts.
Open desktop mode settings to enable a fix for visual glitches caused by input methods
Start desktop mode first before enabling the input method fix

This version of Android does not support freeform mode on displays that do not set their default windowing mode to freeform (such as the built-in device display).\n\nIf you believe this is in error, toggle this setting on to force-enable the \'Freeform mode\" settings page.
